awd_titl_txt: Interactions between speech perception and production during second language learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to communicate in more than one language confers an advantage in business, science, diplomacy, and many other aspects of modern life. To successfully master a new language, an individual must be able to both understand and produce the language. Educators commonly assume that perception and production skills develop in tandem and encourage students to try saying words in the new language on their first day in the classroom. However, recent research suggests that the relationship between speech perception and production is more complex and dynamic, especially when learning to speak and hear sounds that don't occur in languages the learner already knows. Under some circumstances, learners can perceive these novel sounds but may not be able to produce them, or they can produce the sounds without hearing their identity reliably. Compelling new evidence suggests that trying to say novel speech sounds out loud during learning can lead the learner to perceive those sounds less well than learners who do not say the sounds out loud.  To determine how languages are best learned it is necessary to understand the disruptive effect of production on perception. The findings of the proposed research have the potential to inform practice in language teaching. Outreach activities will disseminate results to a broad audience, including a science education project in partnership with The Science Factory, a children's science museum. 

This proposal lays out a series of behavioral studies that systematically investigate both linguistic and non-linguistic factors (such as timing, cognitive load, and quality of productions) that influence perceptual learning and quality of productions of unfamiliar speech sounds. The aim is to understand their unique and joint contributions to perceptual learning. This theoretical account, along with the empirical results, is expected to enhance understanding of the nature of language representations and how they interact with cognitive, linguistic, and situational features. The findings will also contribute to knowledge of the relationship between perception and action more broadly.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated some of the factors that impact learning a novel language. Specifically, we focused on how producing new sounds in a language impacts an individual’s ability to perceive or understand those sounds. It has long been known that an individual’s ability to perceive novel sounds is not correlated with their ability to produce them. Some individuals show much better performance in perception than in production, while others can reliably produce differences between sounds without being able to reliably perceive the differences. Here, we capitalized on a rather counterintuitive finding that, in some cases, when listeners try to say novel sounds out loud during training, they perceive these sounds less well than learners who do not say the sounds out loud. Because this finding is counterintuitive, we conducted multiple experiments to investigate what factors impact this disruption to perceptual learning. 

 

Our results suggest that a variety of factors impact this disruption. Our significant results are summarized below: First, we demonstrated that a combination of task switching and active production of target stimuli result in a disruption to perception learning. Task switching alone results in small disruptions, but these disruptions are most robust when combined with active production of target stimuli. Similarly, producing unrelated items does not result in as robust disruption as production of target stimuli (Baese-Berk, 2019; Baese-Berk & Samuel, 2016).

- Second, we demonstrated that timing of this active production of target stimuli drastically impacts the size of the disruption to perceptual learning (Baese-Berk & Samuel, 2022). Delaying productions by a few seconds results in improved learning compared to immediate production. Interestingly, this time delay does not alleviate disruptions caused by task switching, which suggests that requiring individuals to hold their stimulus-relevant response in memory may result in more learning than stimulus-irrelevant responses. 

- Third, our results suggest that listeners are perhaps not acquiring categories per se. We explore this possibility in a recent position paper (Baese-Berk et al., 2022). If this is the case, we must dramatically rethink L2 speech sound learning, which is the focus of a future grant proposal.

This project resulted in more than three dozen published articles, conference proceedings, theses, book chapters, and/or conference presentations. Further, the project provided scientific training, job and educational opportunities, and career experiences for multiple undergraduate students, two graduate students, and a postdoctoral scholar. The research has had a significant impact on science within the discipline, as shown by over 120 citations to our work in peer-reviewed journal articles and book chapters authored by outside researchers within the field during the project period.

In addition to our scientific findings, we completed two exhibits with the Eugene Science Center, designed and taught a class for first year students and another stand-alone general education course, and did a variety of public outreach programs, including those designed for language teachers.

 

This project contributed significantly to our understanding of language learning, as well as how our brains comprehend and produce speech. This work has the potential to contribute to both language education and to speech therapy for individuals with challenges perceiving and/or producing speech.
